abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Water Supply Development
            Project for Vietnam had a moderately unsatisfactory outcome,
            with the performances of both the Bank and the borrower
            deemed moderately unsatisfactory as well. While some of the
            project development objective indicators and intermediate
            outcome indicators were achieved fully, five were partially
            achieved, while two were not achieved. There were no
            baselines and targets for many of the project outcome and
            output indicators, and so limitations were faced in terms of
            capturing project performance with respect to the original
            intent. The original project scope was significantly reduced
            relative to project design, with this restructuring
            happening at a late stage. Significant lessons learned
            during the implementation of the project were: 1)
            performance based contract could be a good model for
            improving operational efficiency of a water supply utility;
            2) project design should be simple and realistic; 3) a
            modest start and testing innovations before scaling up are
            preferable; 4) a thorough assessment of institutional
            readiness of implementing agencies is necessary; 5)
            effective techniques to handle risks should be implemented;
            6) properly designed and functional monitoring and
            evaluation should be ensured; and 7) a follow through on
            good practices or innovations initiated by the project
            should be ensured.
